stream_context.summary: Kaze worked on an oil rig-themed level for 'Return to Yoshi's Island'. Key activities included implementing a detailed Easter egg for a Builder Koopa involving a custom animation from Zeina and an optimized texture-checking system. He also spent significant time on the design and initial modeling of the level's 'Overseer' Wiggler, deciding on its standing posture and non-combative anger mechanic. The stream also featured discussions on his development philosophy, the move from Twitch to YouTube, and feedback on a new music track from Badub.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is improving code readability and maintainability by refactoring magic numbers for physics and camera settings into named constants with comments, a practice learned from other projects.
development_findings.quote: I took notes from how we work in years for breakfast and I decided I will make all the magic numbers into defines in this file and I even added comic comments that follow some sort of code guidelines.

development_findings.summary: To implement the cement-ruining feature without performance issues, Kaze developed an optimized solution that checks a small, pseudo-random subset of texture pixels (every 176th pixel) instead of the entire texture, approximating the total 'dirtiness' efficiently.
development_findings.quote: I don't want to actually iterate all 16,384 texture particles. I want to just iterate a few random ones everywhere so that it feels like you have to dirty them all.

development_findings.summary: Kaze acknowledges that the physics engine for RTYI has received mixed feedback, with some players loving it and others hating it. He also notes that some complaints are about behaviors inherent to the original Mario 64 engine, like slope rejection.
development_findings.quote: The reception of the current rtyi engine is very mixed I find some people say they love it others say they hate it.

development_findings.summary: Kaze plans to overhaul the screen transition/warp system to make it feel more seamless by allowing Mario's actions and player inputs to continue during the transition instead of the current abrupt cut.
development_findings.quote: I'm gonna completely change the warps... the inputs are just gonna be held maybe I'm gonna make it so that Mario is holding the stick towards the warp and Mario's normal action are just gonna continue while the warp is happening.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is designing the Wiggler character not as a traditional boss fight, but as an 'Overseer' who becomes progressively angrier and redder as the player sabotages his workers on the oil rig, culminating in him giving up and leaving.
Playtest data from a previous project, 'Only Up 64', has provided valuable insights that are being used to improve and refine the physics and camera systems in RTYI.
Kaze decided to model the Wiggler Overseer standing upright, inspired by his appearance in Mario Tennis, and plans to give him arms to better suit this posture.

context_findings.summary: Kaze has moved his streams from Twitch to YouTube because he finds Twitch's ad policy to be excessive and disruptive, even for subscribers.
context_findings.quote: Twitch has gone ad crazy. It's like, unusable. I even get ads when I'm subscribed to people. That shouldn't be happening.

context_findings.summary: Kaze intentionally streams on his secondary YouTube channel to foster a more focused community that is genuinely interested in the game's development.
context_findings.quote: I kind of want to filter this chat to only be the people that actually care about the project. I don't want just a thousand randoms coming in here and talking about random stuff.

context_findings.summary: Kaze believes that being an expert player can be a detriment to designing a good hack for a broader audience, as experts might overlook challenges that casual players face. He emphasizes the importance of designing for a specific target audience.
context_findings.quote: If you're good at Mario 64, there's going to be many random things in your game that you won't notice that casual players will have huge problems with... You have to know your target audience. That's always the key.

context_findings.summary: Kaze compares bragging about high polygon counts in old ROM hacks to bragging about buying expensive clothing, viewing both as signs of inefficiency rather than achievement.
context_findings.quote: Bragging about how much the stuff you have costs is so funny to me. It's like okay all you did was prove that you just managed to get a bad deal.

context_findings.summary: Kaze has no interest in PC-exclusive ports like SM64 EX, stating that if he weren't targeting original N64 hardware, he would use a modern engine instead.
context_findings.quote: If I wanted my game to work on PC exclusively, I would make it in Unreal Engine.

context_findings.summary: Kaze praises Mario Kart Wii for its engaging online mode where players can lose points, creating tension and motivation, which he feels is absent in later titles like Mario Kart 8.
context_findings.quote: I think Mario Kart Wii is the best Mario Kart game to date for a simple reason. It has the only good online mode out of all the Mario Karts.

context_findings.summary: Kaze discusses the possibility of monetizing his Twitter/X account, weighing the potential ad revenue against the cost and perceived stigma of a Twitter Blue subscription.

biobak.summary: Biobak suggested the idea for the Builder Koopa's Easter egg, where the Koopa will start crying if the player ruins enough of the wet cement he is working on.
biobak.quote: Do you want to make me cry?

biobak.summary: Biobak sent Kaze a mockup concept for the Wiggler Overseer wearing a worker's vest, which Kaze considered but ultimately decided against due to the modeling and animation complexity it would introduce.

badub.summary: Badub created a new version of the OST for the current level, which Kaze plays and praises as being better than the first version. The track incorporates sound samples from the Super Smash Bros. Melee menu.
badub.quote: Dude this is melee. You hear that? That was the melee menu.

zeina.summary: Zeina was tasked with creating a sobbing animation for the Builder Koopa. She collaborated with Kaze, suggesting ideas like a stomping tantrum before settling on an animation where the Koopa sits down and cries, which Kaze then implemented.
zeina.quote: Wait, can I give him a stomping tantrum?

zeina.summary: Zeina provided the final looping cry animation for the Builder Koopa, which involved him sitting down on his butt in despair. Kaze noted he needed to separate it into a build-up and a looping part.

key_stories.title: The Crying Koopa Easter Egg
key_stories.summary: The team collaborated to create a detailed Easter egg for a Builder Koopa. Biobak provided the initial concept, Kaze engineered an efficient technical solution to track player interaction, and Zeina created a custom sobbing animation to bring the moment to life.
key_stories.challenge: A viewer, Biobak, suggested an Easter egg where a Builder Koopa would cry if the player completely ruined the wet cement he was working on. This required a new animation and a way to efficiently track how much of the texture had been 'ruined' by Mario's footsteps.
key_stories.process: Kaze first devised a performant way to calculate the 'dirtiness' by checking a small, distributed sample of pixels instead of the entire texture. He then requested a 'sobbing animation' from Zeina. After some iteration to make it distinct from other animations, Zeina created one where the Koopa sits and cries. Kaze implemented the logic, hooked up the animation, and added the final dialogue.
key_stories.outcome: A complete Easter egg was implemented. The Koopa now has a unique sobbing animation and dialogue that triggers when approximately 95% of the cement is ruined, rewarding observant and persistent players.
key_stories.key_quote: Doesn't this look perfect? Like we just cut computation costs into like not even fucking, like basically a 15th.

key_stories.title: Designing the Wiggler Overseer
key_stories.summary: Kaze and the team worked through the conceptual and initial technical design for the Wiggler Overseer character. They decided on his role, his unique reaction mechanic, and a visual design based on his appearance in other Mario games, beginning the process of modeling and rigging him to fit the new concept.
key_stories.challenge: The team needed to design the Wiggler character for the oil rig level. He needed to function as a non-combative 'Overseer' whose mood changes based on the player's actions, and his visual design needed to reflect this role.
key_stories.process: Kaze conceptualized the Wiggler as an Overseer who gets progressively angrier. After looking for real-world inspiration, he was pointed towards the Wiggler's appearance in Mario Tennis. This led to the decision to have him stand upright, which then necessitated adding arms. Kaze began modifying the model, dealing with high polygon counts from the original DS model and beginning to rig the new standing posture.
key_stories.outcome: The team decided on a clear design direction: the Wiggler will stand upright like in Mario Tennis, be given arms, and will be placed in a central location to oversee the level. His animation and texture will change to reflect his growing anger as the player interferes with his workers.
key_stories.key_quote: So he should maybe have some kind of desk that he's working on. So having him have a booth kind of works. It would also be fun if he had like four seats... I can make him stand up like in Mario Tennis. Like that.
